Our doctoral programs are highly selective and turn out top-tier candidates for high-level industry jobs, postdoctoral research positions, and tenure-track faculty roles at universities around the world.       UIC MIE offers two PhD programs:     PhD in Mechanical Engineering   Conduct research on the forefront of biomedical engineering, computational mechanics, energy, microscale and nanoscale science and engineering, and other areas.     PhD in Industrial Engineering and Operations Research   Develop expertise in core disciplines in industrial engineering, such as data-driven decision-making and design, controls, and manufacturing.          Program Overview   The PhD requires 108 semester hours, beginning with coursework and culminating in the research, writing, and defense of an original dissertation. UIC MIE welcomes applicants who are completing (or who have already completed) a master’s degree in their field as well as applicants with only an undergraduate degree.  For students admitted with a prior master’s degree in their field of study , the degree requirements for the PhD in mechanical engineering or the PhD in industrial engineering and operations research include 24 credit hours of traditional coursework, 52 credit hours of doctoral-level research, and semesterly enrollment in the zero-credit ME 595 or IE 595 Departmental Seminar, which builds students’ current knowledge of the field by exposing them to presentations from UIC scholars and external researchers.  For students who are directly admitted after a bachelor’s degree in their field of study , the degree requirements for the PhD in mechanical engineering or the PhD in industrial engineering and operations research include 48 hours of traditional coursework, 60 credits of doctoral-level research, and semesterly enrollment in the zero-credit ME 595 or IE 595 Departmental Seminar.  Please expand the sections below to learn about the requirements in more detail.       PhD Degree Requirements     PhD in Mechanical Engineering with a prior MS degree         ME requirements   24 credit hours of coursework   12 of these credit hours must be at the 500 level, excluding ME 596, ME 598, and ME 599. At least 8 of these credit hours must be ME courses. 4 credit hours of ME 594 may be used toward this requirement.  The remaining 12 of these credit hours must be in courses at the 400 level or 500 level. At least 4 of these credit hours must be ME courses. Up to 4 hours of ME 596 and up to 4 hours of 400-level or 500-level mathematics and statistics can be used toward this requirement.   52 credit hours of research   Students must complete 52 hours of ME 599 PhD Thesis Research.   Additional notes   Students must enroll in and complete the ME 595 Departmental Seminar in all fall and spring semesters.  Students must get the director of graduate studies’ approval to take online courses.  All courses must be approved first by the student’s advisor and then by the director of graduate studies.  No credit toward the degree will be given for courses taken as credit/no-credit. At least 12 of these credit hours must be ME courses. 4 credit hours of ME 594 may be used toward this requirement.  The remaining 24 of these credit hours must be in courses at the 400 level or 500 level. At least 8 of these credit hours must be ME courses. Up to 4 hours of ME 596 and up to 4 hours of 400-level or 500-level mathematics and statistics can be used toward this requirement.   60 credit hours of research   Students must complete 60 hours of ME 599 PhD Thesis Research. Preliminary Examination   PhD students must pass a preliminary examination before they begin the final phase of their doctoral study. Visit the Preliminary Examination page for full details.       Dissertation Process   Upon completion of all degree requirements and the dissertation, students must orally defend their work before their committee.
